    # Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Patient has had multiple episodes of
   flash pulmonary edema requiring intubation during his multiple MICU and
   CCU admissions, with this episode consistent with prior episodes.
   Although flash pulmonary edema is the most likely etiology of his
   hypoxic respiratory failure, other potential etiologies include ACS or
   PE, although these are less likely given his history and unchanged ECGs
   and supratherapeutic INR.   Flash pulmonary edema likely [**1-26**] anxiety,
   will attempt to control triggers of anxiety.
   - Nitro gtt, titrate to SBP<100
   - Titrate up bowel regimen
   - Will chart bx in regards to hx colonoscopy, consider consulting GI
   for scope if no records
   - Start amytriptyline today, will monitor QT interval
   - Isordil 5mg tid with MAP goal >50 in attempt to prevent pulmonary
   edema
   - Diuresis as needed for volume overload
   - Extubate today
   .
   #  Pump:  Patient presented with fluid overload, likely exacerbation of
   well known systolic CHF (EF 20%). Pt with significant diuresis this
   stay, will hold lasix gtt but continue
   -Diurese with lasix gtt
   .
   # UTI: Pt urine culture positive for ESBL Klebsiella.
    - Condom catheter to monitor I/Os, UOP
   - Continue meropenem for 14 d course (day 1=[**9-20**]).
   .
   # Coronaries:  Patient has known CAD s/p CABG. Recent cath showed 2VD,
   patent LIMA to LAD, and diastolic dysfunction with no interventions
   performed.
   - Continue ASA and statin
   - Continue ACE-I and BB
   .
   # Rhythmn:  Currently in sinus with 1:1 conduction.  Patient has
   history of VF arrest with AICD removal given recurrent  bloodstream
   infections.
   -monitor on telemetry
   .
   #  Blood pressure: Tolerating SBPs in the 80s.
   - Anti-hypertensive regimen as above.
   .
   # R leg ulcer: s/p surgical debridement by VSurg [**9-8**]. Wound VAC placed
   [**9-9**].
   - Continue wound VAC with replacement 3x/wk (MWF schedule).
   .
   # [**Month/Year (2) 4969**]: Goal INR 2.5 - 3.5. INR today was 3.6.
   - Continue Coumadin at half dose as on meropenem (2mg PO daily is the
   new dose starting today).
   .
   # DM 2:  Continue glargine 120 u qHS, ISS with accuchecks.
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia:- Continue atorvastatin.
   .
   # Hep C:  Per Hepatology, deferring treatment for now. [**Month (only) 60**] consider
   reassessment if patient continues to improve.
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Not currently on thyroid replacement therapy given
   that last TSH was appropriate.
   .
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: diabetic/cardiac diet
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines: PIV, PICC
   PICC Line - [**2178-9-20**] 09:38 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: warfarin
   Stress ulcer: H2B
   VAP:  extubate today.
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments: wife, [**Name (NI) 845**] [**Name (NI) 10366**], [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10145**]
   Code status: Full (confirmed)
   Disposition: CCU for now
   ------ Protected Section ------
   Cardiology Teaching Physician Note
   On this day I saw, examined and was physically present with the
   resident / fellow for the key portions of the services provided. I
   agree with the above note and plans.
   I would add the following remarks:
   Total time spent on patient care: 35 minutes of critical care time.
   Additional comments:
   date/time of visit was 9/28/9 at 1115 am.  Critically ill due to acute
   systolic and diastolic CHF, acute pulmonary edema, renal failure,
   urosepsis.
   ------ Protected Section Addendum Entered By:[**Name (NI) 391**] [**Name (NI) **], MD
   on:[**2178-9-21**] 16:51 ------

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old gentleman with a significant cardiac history, including coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) and a history of ventricular fibrillation (VF) arrest. He has been admitted to the ICU multiple times due to episodes of flash pulmonary edema, requiring intubation.

Current status:

* The patient is intubated and receiving CPAP/PSV ventilation.
* He has a heart rate of 65 beats per minute, blood pressure of 88/46 mmHg, and a respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute.
* His oxygen saturation is 99%, and his ABG values are within normal limits.
* He has a first-degree atrioventricular (AV) block and a systolic murmur throughout the precordium.
* His abdomen is soft, with decreased bowel sounds and mild tenderness to palpation in the left lower quadrant (LLQ).
* He has a wound in the right lower extremity (RLE) with a clean dressing in place and 2+ edema.
* His neurologic examination is normal, with the patient being responsive to questioning.

Lab results:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 13.4
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 7.7 g/dL
* Platelet count (Plt): 265
* Creatinine (Cr): 1.3 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.12 ng/mL
* TCO2: 31
* Glucose: 150 mg/dL
* Other lab values are within normal limits.

Potential medical complications:

* Flash pulmonary edema: The patient has a history of episodes of flash pulmonary edema, which can lead to respiratory failure and cardiac arrest.
* Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of VF arrest and is at risk for further cardiac complications, such as atrial fibrillation or cardiac tamponade.
* Renal failure: The patient has a creatinine level of 1.3 mg/dL, which may indicate renal failure or impaired renal function.
* Urosepsis: The patient has a urine culture positive for ESBL Klebsiella, which may lead to urosepsis or septic shock.
* Hypothyroidism: The patient has a history of hypothyroidism, which may require thyroid replacement therapy.
* Hepatitis C: The patient has a history of hepatitis C, which may require treatment.

Plan:

* Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and lab values.
* Titrate the nitroglycerin infusion to control blood pressure and prevent pulmonary edema.
* Continue diuresis as needed for volume overload.
* Consider extubation today.
* Continue antibiotic therapy for urosepsis.
* Monitor the patient's cardiac status and consider cardioversion if necessary.
* Continue to manage the patient's wound in the RLE.
* Monitor the patient's neurologic status and consider imaging if necessary.
* Continue to manage the patient's hypothyroidism and hepatitis C.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old gentleman with a history of multiple recent intubations due to episodes of flash pulmonary edema, significant cardiac history including CABG, and VF arrest with AICD placement. He is currently intubated and receiving invasive ventilation.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Tmax: 36.1°C (97°F)
* Tcurrent: 36.1°C (97°F)
* HR: 65 bpm (48-94 bpm)
* BP: 88/46 mmHg (57-169/98 mmHg)
* RR: 12 inspirations per minute (12-21 inspirations per minute)
* SpO2: 99%

The patient has a history of flash pulmonary edema, which is likely exacerbated by anxiety. The healthcare team plans to control triggers of anxiety and consider initiating long-term anxiolytic therapy.

The patient also has a history of systolic CHF (EF 20%) and has diuresed approximately 2.5 L this stay. The healthcare team plans to continue diuresis with lasix gtt.

The patient's urine culture is positive for ESBL Klebsiella, and he is receiving meropenem therapy. He has a history of VF arrest with AICD removal due to recurrent infections.

The patient's cardiac biomarkers are elevated, and he has a history of CAD s/p CABG. The healthcare team plans to continue ASA and statin therapy.

The patient's INR is supratherapeutic, and he is receiving Coumadin at half dose. He has a history of DM2, hyperlipidemia, and hypothyroidism.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Further episodes of flash pulmonary edema
* Development of acute coronary syndrome (ACS)
* Pulmonary embolism (PE)
* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
* Stress ulcer bleeding
* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
* Sepsis due to his positive urine culture
* Wound infection due to his R leg ulcer
* Hypothyroidism
* Hyperglycemia
* Hypoglycemia
* Electrolyte imbalances
* QT interval prolongation due to anxiolytic therapy
* Bleeding due to supratherapeutic INR

The healthcare team plans to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust therapy as needed to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health status as follows:

* The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of cardiac issues, including coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), ventricular fibrillation (VF) arrest, and atrial fibrillation (AF) with an implanted cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD) removed due to bacteremia.
* He has been admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) multiple times for episodes of flash pulmonary edema, requiring intubation.
* Currently, he is intubated and receiving invasive ventilation, with a recent episode of flash pulmonary edema that was controlled with nitroglycerin.
* His vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 65 beats per minute, blood pressure of 88/46 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 99%.
* He has a history of systolic heart failure (EF 20%) and is receiving diuretic therapy.
* His urine culture is positive for extended-spectrum beta-lactamase (ESBL) Klebsiella, and he is receiving meropenem for a 14-day course.
* He has a known coronary artery disease (CAD) with a patent left internal mammary artery (LIMA) to left anterior descending (LAD) artery and diastolic dysfunction.
* His blood pressure is tolerating systolic blood pressures in the 80s, and he is receiving antihypertensive therapy.
* He has a right leg ulcer that was surgically debridement and is being treated with a wound vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) device.
* His international normalized ratio (INR) is 3.6, and he is receiving warfarin for prophylaxis.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Pneumonia: Given his history of flash pulmonary edema and intubation, he is at risk for developing pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: His positive urine culture and receipt of meropenem for a 14-day course suggest that he may be at risk for developing sepsis.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: His history of VF arrest and AF with an implanted AICD removed due to bacteremia suggest that he may be at risk for developing cardiac arrhythmias.
4. Bleeding: His receipt of warfarin for prophylaxis and his history of bleeding complications may put him at risk for bleeding complications.
5. Wound infection: His right leg ulcer and receipt of wound VAC therapy may put him at risk for developing wound infection.
6. Hypothyroidism: His history of hypothyroidism and lack of thyroid replacement therapy may put him at risk for developing hypothyroidism.
7. Hyperlipidemia: His receipt of atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia may put him at risk for developing hyperlipidemia-related complications.

Based on this information, it appears that the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 65-year-old male admitted to the ICU for hypoxic respiratory failure due to flash pulmonary edema, which is likely related to anxiety. He has a history of systolic heart failure, coronary artery disease, and atrial fibrillation. He is currently intubated and receiving invasive ventilation. His vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 65 beats per minute, blood pressure of 88/46 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 99%. His laboratory results show elevated troponin levels, indicating cardiac damage. He has a positive urine culture for ESBL Klebsiella and is receiving meropenem for treatment.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is at risk for developing VAP due to his prolonged intubation and presence of a central venous catheter.
2. Catheter-related bloodstream infection (CRBSI): The patient has a PICC line, which increases his risk for developing a CRBSI.
3. Sepsis: The patient's positive urine culture and elevated white blood cell count suggest that he may be at risk for developing sepsis.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of systolic heart failure and coronary artery disease increases his risk for cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, cardiac arrest, and heart failure.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxic respiratory failure may worsen if he develops respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding and the presence of a central venous catheter increase his risk for developing gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding or perforation.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and the presence of a central venous catheter increase his risk for developing neurological complications, such as stroke or seizures.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely to identify any changes or complications.
2. Implement strategies to prevent VAP, such as elevating the head of the bed and ensuring proper hand hygiene.
3. Monitor the patient's PICC line for signs of infection and consider removing it if necessary.
4. Continue to treat the patient's urinary tract infection with meropenem and monitor his response to treatment.
5. Consider adjusting the patient's cardiac medications to optimize his cardiac function and reduce his risk for cardiac complications.
6. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider intubating him if he develops respiratory failure.
7. Consider consulting with a gastrointestinal specialist to evaluate the patient's gastrointestinal bleeding and develop a plan to prevent further bleeding.

Summary:

The patient is a 65-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of hypoxic respiratory failure. He has a history of systolic CHF, CAD, and has undergone CABG. He is currently intubated and receiving invasive ventilation. He has a PICC line in place and is receiving various medications, including fentanyl, midazolam, and meropenem.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.1°C, heart rate of 65 bpm, and blood pressure of 88/46 mmHg. His oxygen saturation is 99% on 40% FiO2. His respiratory support includes CPAP/PSV ventilation with a tidal volume of 550 mL and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin-T levels, indicating myocardial injury. His complete blood count shows a white blood cell count of 13.4 K/uL and a platelet count of 265 K/uL. His electrolyte levels are normal, except for a slightly elevated potassium level.

The patient's medical history includes a history of VF arrest, AICD removal, and recurrent infections. He has also had multiple episodes of flash pulmonary edema requiring intubation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's prolonged intubation and respiratory support increase his risk of developing VAP.
2. Sepsis: The patient's positive urine culture for ESBL Klebsiella and his history of recurrent infections increase his risk of developing sepsis.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of CAD, systolic CHF, and elevated troponin-T levels increase his risk of developing cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.
4. Renal failure: The patient's fluid overload and history of systolic CHF increase his risk of developing renal failure.
5. Wound infection: The patient's R leg ulcer and wound VAC placement increase his risk of developing wound infection.
6. Bleeding complications: The patient's supratherapeutic INR and history of AICD removal increase his risk of bleeding complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely.
2. Adjust the patient's respiratory support as needed to prevent VAP.
3. Continue to treat the patient's UTI with meropenem and monitor his urine output.
4. Consider adding antibiotics to cover for potential cardiac complications.
5. Monitor the patient's fluid status and adjust his diuretic regimen as needed to prevent fluid overload and renal failure.
6. Monitor the patient's wound for signs of infection and adjust his wound care regimen as needed.
7. Consider restarting the patient's coumadin when his INR is within the therapeutic range.
8. Monitor the patient's cardiac biomarkers and adjust his cardiac medication regimen as needed.

Summary:

The patient is a 65-year-old male admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a chief complaint of hypoxic respiratory failure. He has a history of systolic heart failure, coronary artery disease, and atrial fibrillation. The patient is currently intubated and receiving invasive ventilation, with a tidal volume of 550 mL and a respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 99%, and his blood pressure is 88/46 mmHg. He has a history of flash pulmonary edema, which is likely the cause of his current respiratory failure.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin levels, indicating cardiac damage. His electrolyte levels are abnormal, with hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, and hyperphosphatemia. His liver enzymes are also elevated, with a significant increase in his alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level.

The patient's medications include fentanyl, midazolam, and meropenem, which is being continued due to a positive urine culture for ESBL Klebsiella. He is also receiving diuretics, including lasix and torsemide, to manage his fluid overload.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to flash pulmonary edema, but other potential causes include acute coronary syndrome (ACS) or pulmonary embolism (PE).
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and recent cardiac biomarker elevations increase his risk for cardiac arrhythmias.
3. Infection: The patient's positive urine culture for ESBL Klebsiella increases his risk for sepsis and septic shock.
4. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid overload is likely exacerbating his respiratory failure and may lead to further complications, such as acute kidney injury or cardiac failure.
5. Bleeding: The patient's supratherapeutic INR increases his risk for bleeding complications, particularly with the use of anticoagulant medications.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient's history of hypothyroidism may be contributing to his cardiac problems and electrolyte imbalances.
7. Hepatitis C: The patient's history of hepatitis C may be contributing to his liver enzyme elevations and increasing his risk for liver-related complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to manage the patient's respiratory failure with invasive ventilation and diuretics.
2. Monitor the patient's cardiac biomarkers and consider further cardiac testing to rule out ACS or PE.
3. Continue antibiotic therapy for the patient's urinary tract infection (UTI) and monitor for signs of sepsis or septic shock.
4. Monitor the patient's fluid status and electrolyte levels to prevent further complications.
5. Consider adjusting the patient's anticoagulant medications to reduce his risk for bleeding complications.
6. Consider re-evaluating the patient's thyroid status and considering thyroid replacement therapy if necessary.
7. Consider further evaluation of the patient's hepatitis C status and potential treatment options.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a chief complaint of acute on chronic systolic heart failure. They have been on invasive ventilation since September 20, 2022, at 9:09 PM. The patient has a urinary tract infection (UTI) and impaired skin integrity. They have been receiving various medications, including fentanyl and midazolam, and have had several lab tests and imaging studies performed.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.1°C, heart rate of 65 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 88/46 mmHg. Their respiratory status is stable, with an oxygen saturation of 99% and a respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute. The patient's hemodynamic monitoring is stable, with a cardiac output index of 2.3 L/min and a central venous pressure of 15 mmHg.

The patient's lab results show elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and troponin levels, indicating possible cardiac damage. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, with the exception of a slightly elevated potassium level.

Potential medical complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Given the patient's prolonged use of invasive ventilation, there is a risk of developing VAP.
2. Sepsis: The patient's UTI and impaired skin integrity increase their risk of developing sepsis.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's acute on chronic systolic heart failure and elevated troponin levels suggest a risk of cardiac complications, such as cardiogenic shock or arrhythmias.
4. Skin breakdown: The patient's impaired skin integrity increases their risk of developing pressure ulcers or skin breakdown.
5. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's prolonged ICU stay and impaired gut function may lead to nutritional deficiencies, such as malnutrition or electrolyte imbalances.

Based on the patient's condition and potential complications, it is essential to continue monitoring their vital signs, lab results, and respiratory status closely. Additionally, the patient's family and healthcare providers should be informed of the patient's condition and potential complications to ensure proper care and management.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual in the ICU, receiving invasive ventilation and PICC line infusions. They have a history of antibiotic use, including meropenem, and are currently receiving fentanyl and midazolam infusions. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.1°C, heart rate of 65 bpm, and blood pressure of 88/46 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is being monitored, with a respiratory rate of 12 inspirations per minute and an SpO2 of 99%. The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and creatinine levels.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is receiving invasive ventilation, which increases the risk of developing VAP. Close monitoring of respiratory cultures and antibiotic therapy is essential to prevent this complication.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and platelet count suggest the possibility of sepsis. Close monitoring of vital signs, laboratory results, and antibiotic therapy is necessary to prevent sepsis progression.
3. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels suggest the possibility of renal failure. Close monitoring of urine output, electrolytes, and creatinine levels is necessary to prevent acute kidney injury.
4. Bleeding complications: The patient is receiving anticoagulant therapy, which increases the risk of bleeding complications. Close monitoring of bleeding signs and symptoms is necessary to prevent bleeding complications.
5. Delirium: The patient's altered mental status and lack of response to stimuli suggest the possibility of delirium. Close monitoring of mental status and administration of sedatives and analgesics as needed is necessary to prevent delirium progression.
6. Pressure ulcers: The patient's immobility and decreased sensation increase the risk of pressure ulcers. Close monitoring of skin integrity and regular turning and repositioning are necessary to prevent pressure ulcers.
7. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient is at risk for DVT due to immobility and central venous catheter placement. Close monitoring of lower extremity circulation and administration of prophylactic anticoagulant therapy are necessary to prevent DVT.

   # Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Patient has had multiple episodes of
   flash pulmonary edema requiring intubation during his multiple MICU and
   CCU admissions; this episode was consistent with prior episodes.
   Although flash pulmonary edema is the most likely etiology of his
   hypoxic respiratory failure, other potential etiologies include ACS or
   PE, although these are less likely given his history, unchanged ECGs,
   and supratherapeutic INR.   Perhaps anxiety provoked his flash
   pulmonary edema, but unclear if vice-versa is the case. Will attempt to
   control triggers of anxiety (ie: constipation). Extubated yesterday
   successfully ([**9-21**]).
   - Goal: 1L out today
   - Start spironolactone 12.5mg daily
   - Continue lasix drip at 20mg/hour and titrate as needed to meet goal
   diuresis
   - Amytriptyline started [**9-21**], will monitor QT interval
   - Isordil 10mg tid with MAP goal >50 in attempt to prevent pulmonary
   edema
   .
   #  Pump:  Patient presented with fluid overload, likely exacerbation of
   well known systolic CHF (EF 20%). Pt with significant diuresis this
   stay, almost net negative 1L over past 24 hours.
   -Continue to diurese with lasix gtt and start spironolactone today
   .
   # UTI: Pt urine culture positive for ESBL Klebsiella.
   - Condom catheter to monitor I/Os, UOP
   - Continue meropenem for 14 d course (day 1=[**9-20**]).
   .
   # Coronaries:  Patient has known CAD s/p CABG. Recent cath showed 2VD,
   patent LIMA to LAD, and diastolic dysfunction with no interventions
   performed.
   - Continue ASA and statin
   - Continue ACE-I and BB
   .
   # Rhythmn:  Currently in sinus with 1:1 conduction.  Patient has
   history of VF arrest with AICD removal given recurrent bloodstream
   infections.
   -monitor on telemetry
   .
   #  Constipation:
   - Continue bowel regimen (feels constipated, although last BM was
   yesterday evening (large, soft))
   - Patient denies prior colonoscopy; consider colonoscopy as outpatient
   .
   #  Blood pressure: Tolerating SBPs in the 80s.
   - Anti-hypertensive regimen as above.
   .
   # R leg ulcer: s/p surgical debridement by VSurg [**9-8**]. Wound VAC placed
   [**9-9**].  Most recent wound care rec is to not have a VAC in place
   (previously was: continue wound VAC with replacement 3x/wk (MWF
   schedule)).
   - Follow-up vascular recommendations today
   .
   # AVR: Goal INR 2.5 - 3.5. INR today is 2.7.
   - Resume coumadin at home dose, 5 mg daily
   .
   # DM 2:  Continue glargine 120 u qHS, ISS with accuchecks.
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: Continue atorvastatin.
   .
   # Hep C:  Per Hepatology, deferring treatment for now. [**Month (only) 60**] consider
   reassessment if patient continues to improve.
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Not currently on thyroid replacement therapy given
   that last TSH was appropriate.
   .
   # Hypokalemia:
   - Not going to replete K as starting spironolocatone
   - Check 3pm electrolytes

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of a sore right foot. He has a history of chronic systolic and diastolic heart failure, coronary artery disease, and has undergone coronary artery bypass grafting. He has also been diagnosed with hyperlipidemia, hypothyroidism, and hepatitis C.

The patient has been experiencing flash pulmonary edema, which has required intubation and mechanical ventilation. He has also had episodes of hypoxic respiratory failure, which has led to his current admission to the ICU.

The patient's current medications include:

* Furosemide (Lasix) 20 mg/hour IV
* Heparin Sodium (Prophylaxis) 5000 units/hour IV
* Spironolactone 12.5 mg daily
* Isordil 10 mg tid
* Amytriptyline 25 mg qHS
* Meropenem 1 g IV every 8 hours

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 7.2 g/dL
* Platelet count: 247 K/uL
* White blood cell count: 10.5 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.12 ng/mL
* CK-MB: 3.0 ng/mL
* Glucose: 120 mg/dL

Potential medical complications:

* Hypoxic respiratory failure
* Flash pulmonary edema
* Acute coronary syndrome
* Pulmonary embolism
* Constipation
* Hypokalemia
* Hyperlipidemia
* Hypothyroidism
* Hepatitis C
* Peripheral vascular disease

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's current condition is critical, with multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS) and acute kidney injury (AKI). The patient requires close monitoring and management of his respiratory, cardiovascular, and renal function. The patient's medication regimen will be continued and adjusted as necessary to manage his condition.

The patient will be followed up with a cardiology teaching physician note and will be seen by a vascular surgeon for further evaluation and management of his peripheral vascular disease. The patient's wife will be updated on his condition and will be contacted for any changes in his status.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with a history of multiple ICU and CCU admissions for hypoxic respiratory failure, flash pulmonary edema, and cardiac issues. The patient has been intubated and is currently receiving invasive ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.3°C, heart rate of 77 bpm, and blood pressure of 88/46 mmHg. The patient's respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 96%. The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a central venous pressure (CVP) of 1,347 mL, and a total fluid balance of -973 mL.

The patient has a history of cardiac issues, including systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 20%. The patient's cardiac medications include aspirin, statin, ACE-I, and beta-blocker.

The patient has a urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by ESBL Klebsiella, and is being treated with meropenem for a 14-day course. The patient's wound VAC has been placed, and the patient is being monitored for signs of infection.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but the patient is still intubated and receiving invasive ventilation.
2. Cardiac issues: The patient has a history of cardiac issues, including systolic heart failure, and is at risk for cardiac complications.
3. UTI: The patient has a UTI caused by ESBL Klebsiella, and is at risk for developing sepsis.
4. Infection: The patient's wound VAC has been placed, and the patient is at risk for developing infection.
5. Fluid overload: The patient has a history of fluid overload, and is at risk for developing pulmonary edema.

The patient's plan includes:

1. Continued invasive ventilation to support the patient's respiratory status.
2. Monitoring of the patient's cardiac status, including cardiac enzymes and echocardiogram.
3. Treatment of the patient's UTI with meropenem for a 14-day course.
4. Monitoring of the patient's wound VAC for signs of infection.
5. Management of the patient's fluid overload with diuresis and monitoring of the patient's central venous pressure.

   Assessment and Plan
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Patient has had multiple episodes of
   flash pulmonary edema requiring intubation during his multiple MICU and
   CCU admissions; this episode was consistent with prior episodes.
   Although flash pulmonary edema is the most likely etiology of his
   hypoxic respiratory failure, other potential etiologies include ACS or
   PE, although these are less likely given his history, unchanged ECGs,
   and supratherapeutic INR.   Perhaps anxiety provoked his flash
   pulmonary edema, but unclear if vice-versa is the case. Will attempt to
   control triggers of anxiety (ie: constipation). Extubated yesterday
   successfully ([**9-21**]).
   - Goal: 1L out today
   - Start spironolactone 12.5mg daily
   - Continue lasix drip at 20mg/hour and titrate as needed to meet goal
   diuresis
   - Amytriptyline started [**9-21**], will monitor QT interval
   - Isordil 10mg tid with MAP goal >50 in attempt to prevent pulmonary
   edema
   .
   #  Pump:  Patient presented with fluid overload, likely exacerbation of
   well known systolic CHF (EF 20%). Pt with significant diuresis this
   stay, almost net negative 1L over past 24 hours.
   -Continue to diurese with lasix gtt and start spironolactone today
   .
   # UTI: Pt urine culture positive for ESBL Klebsiella.
   - Condom catheter to monitor I/Os, UOP
   - Continue meropenem for 14 d course (day 1=[**9-20**]).
   .
   # Coronaries:  Patient has known CAD s/p CABG. Recent cath showed 2VD,
   patent LIMA to LAD, and diastolic dysfunction with no interventions
   performed.
   - Continue ASA and statin
   - Continue ACE-I and BB
   .
   # Rhythmn:  Currently in sinus with 1:1 conduction.  Patient has
   history of VF arrest with AICD removal given recurrent bloodstream
   infections.
   -monitor on telemetry
   .
   #  Constipation:
   - Continue bowel regimen (feels constipated, although last BM was
   yesterday evening (large, soft))
   - Patient denies prior colonoscopy; consider colonoscopy as outpatient
   .
   #  Blood pressure: Tolerating SBPs in the 80s.
   - Anti-hypertensive regimen as above.
   .
   # R leg ulcer: s/p surgical debridement by VSurg [**9-8**]. Wound VAC placed
   [**9-9**].  Most recent wound care rec is to not have a VAC in place
   (previously was: continue wound VAC with replacement 3x/wk (MWF
   schedule)).
   - Follow-up vascular recommendations today
   .
   # [**Month/Year (2) 4969**]: Goal INR 2.5 - 3.5. INR today is 2.7.
   - Resume coumadin at home dose, 5 mg daily
   .
   # DM 2:  Continue glargine 120 u qHS, ISS with accuchecks.
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: Continue atorvastatin.
   .
   # Hep C:  Per Hepatology, deferring treatment for now. [**Month (only) 60**] consider
   reassessment if patient continues to improve.
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Not currently on thyroid replacement therapy given
   that last TSH was appropriate.
   .
   # Hypokalemia:
   - Not going to replete K as starting spironolocatone
   - Check 3pm electrolytes

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 72-year-old male who has been admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of a sore right foot. The patient has a history of cardiac issues, including coronary artery disease and a previous heart attack, and has undergone cardiac catheterization and coronary artery bypass grafting.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: The patient's temperature is 37.3°C, heart rate is 77 beats per minute, blood pressure is 88/46 mmHg, respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 96%.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient's central venous pressure is 12 mmHg, pulmonary artery pressure is 28 mmHg, and cardiac index is 2.3 L/min/m².
* Respiratory support: The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a peak inspiratory pressure of 10 cmH2O, positive end-expiratory pressure of 0 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen of 40%.
* Laboratory results: The patient's white blood cell count is 10.5 x 10⁹/L, hemoglobin is 7.2 g/dL, and platelet count is 222 x 10⁹/L. The patient's blood urea nitrogen is 28 mg/dL, creatinine is 1.2 mg/dL, and serum potassium is 4.2 mmol/L.

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Hypoxic respiratory failure
* Fluid overload
* Coronary artery disease
* Chronic heart failure
* Chronic kidney disease
* Hyperlipidemia
* Hepatitis C
* Hypothyroidism
* Hypokalemia

The patient's medications include:

* Furosemide (Lasix) 20 mg/hour IV
* Heparin sodium (Prophylaxis) 5000 units/hour IV
* Famotidine (Pepcid) 20 mg IV every 8 hours
* Spironolactone 12.5 mg daily oral
* Amytriptyline 25 mg daily oral
* Isordil 10 mg three times daily oral
* Atorvastatin 80 mg daily oral
* Glargine 120 units daily subcutaneous
* Coumadin 5 mg daily oral

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Pneumonia
* Ventilator-associated pneumonia
* Sepsis
* Acute respiratory distress syndrome
* Cardiac arrest
* Myocardial infarction
* Stroke
* Chronic kidney disease progression
* Hepatitis C progression

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue mechanical ventilation and adjust as needed
* Continue diuresis with furosemide and spironolactone
* Monitor for signs of hypokalemia and adjust potassium levels as needed
* Continue anticoagulation with heparin sodium
* Continue antihypertensive medications
* Continue lipid-lowering medications
* Continue antiviral medications for hepatitis C
* Monitor for signs of thyroid dysfunction and adjust thyroid hormone levels as needed
* Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust medications as needed.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of right foot soreness. He has a history of cardiac disease, including coronary artery disease, heart failure, and atrial fibrillation. He was recently extubated after experiencing flash pulmonary edema, which was likely related to his underlying heart failure. The patient is currently on invasive ventilation, and his respiratory status is being closely monitored. He has a urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by an extended-spectrum beta-lactamase (ESBL) Klebsiella and is being treated with meropenem. The patient also has a right leg ulcer that was surgically debrided and is being treated with a wound vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) system.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pneumonia: Given the patient's history of flash pulmonary edema and his current respiratory status, there is a risk of developing pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: The patient's UTI and underlying cardiac disease increase his risk of developing sepsis.
3. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and ventricular fibrillation (VF) arrest increases his risk of cardiac arrest.
4. Pulmonary Embolism (PE): The patient's history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE) increases his risk of developing another PE.
5. Kidney Injury: The patient's history of heart failure and use of diuretics increases his risk of developing kidney injury.
6. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient's use of diuretics and potassium-sparing medications increases his risk of developing electrolyte imbalances, particularly hypokalemia.
7. Wound Infection: The patient's right leg ulcer increases his risk of developing a wound infection.
8. Hepatitis C: The patient's history of hepatitis C increases his risk of developing liver disease and liver failure.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's current condition is stable, but he requires close monitoring and management of his underlying medical conditions. The patient's respiratory status is being closely monitored, and he is receiving treatment for his UTI. The patient's right leg ulcer is being treated with a wound VAC system, and he is receiving prophylactic antibiotics to prevent wound infection. The patient's cardiac medications are being continued, and he is being monitored for signs of cardiac instability. The patient's electrolyte levels are being closely monitored, and he is receiving treatment for his hypokalemia. The patient's wound care is being continued, and he is being monitored for signs of wound infection.

Summary:

The patient is a 60-year-old male who has been admitted to the ICU with a history of chronic systolic heart failure, acute on chronic, and has been experiencing flash pulmonary edema. He has been intubated multiple times during his previous hospitalizations. The patient's current condition is stable, but he continues to experience episodes of hypoxic respiratory failure, which is likely related to flash pulmonary edema. He has also been diagnosed with urinary tract infection (UTI) and has a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) with a patent left internal mammary artery (LIMA) to left anterior descending (LAD) artery.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin-T levels, indicating cardiac injury, and anemia, which may be related to chronic heart failure. His coagulation profile shows a prolonged international normalized ratio (INR), which may be related to his history of bleeding complications.

The patient's physical examination is notable for a harsh systolic murmur auscultated throughout the left upper chest, with the loudest volume at the right upper sternal border (RUSB). His skin examination shows vascular insufficiency browning changes in his right leg, and his neurological examination is normal.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pulmonary Edema: The patient's history of flash pulmonary edema and chronic systolic heart failure increases his risk of developing pulmonary edema, which can lead to respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's history of ventricular fibrillation (VF) arrest and his current cardiac status increase his risk of cardiac arrest.
3. Sepsis: The patient's UTI and history of bloodstream infections increase his risk of developing sepsis, which can lead to organ failure.
4. Skin Breakdown: The patient's skin examination shows vascular insufficiency browning changes in his right leg, which may increase his risk of skin breakdown and pressure ulcers.
5. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's history of chronic heart failure and his current condition increase his risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as constipation and diarrhea.
6. Renal Complications: The patient's history of chronic heart failure and his current condition increase his risk of developing renal complications, such as acute kidney injury.
7. Respiratory Complications: The patient's history of chronic heart failure and his current condition increase his risk of developing respiratory complications, such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is stable, but he continues to experience episodes of hypoxic respiratory failure. His treatment plan includes:

1. Continue diuresis with Lasix to manage fluid overload and pulmonary edema.
2. Monitor his cardiac status closely and adjust his medications as necessary.
3. Continue antibiotics for his UTI and monitor for signs of sepsis.
4. Monitor his skin integrity and prevent skin breakdown.
5. Manage his gastrointestinal symptoms and prevent constipation and diarrhea.
6. Monitor his renal function and adjust his medications as necessary.
7. Monitor his respiratory status and adjust his medications as necessary.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 109.4 kg male who has been admitted to the ICU with a history of chronic systolic heart failure, coronary artery disease, and chronic kidney disease. He has been experiencing episodes of flash pulmonary edema, which has led to hypoxic respiratory failure. He has been intubated and is currently on a lasix drip to manage fluid overload.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure ranging from 76/38 to 116/57 mmHg, heart rate of 64-93 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. His respiratory rate is 17 inspirations per minute, and his temperature is 36.4°C.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin levels, indicating myocardial damage. His creatinine level is 1.3 mg/dL, and his potassium level is 3.7 mmol/L. His white blood cell count is 8.0 x 10^9/L, and his platelet count is 274 x 10^9/L.

The patient has a history of urinary tract infections and has been prescribed meropenem for 14 days. He has also been prescribed spironolactone, furosemide, and isordil to manage his heart failure and fluid overload.

The patient's skin is showing signs of vascular insufficiency, with browning changes in his right leg. He has a history of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism, and is currently on warfarin for prophylaxis.

The patient's abdominal examination is normal, with no signs of organomegaly or tenderness. His neurological examination is normal, with no signs of focal deficits or altered mental status.

Based on the patient's condition, potential medical complications that could arise include:

1. Further episodes of flash pulmonary edema, which could lead to worsening hypoxic respiratory failure.
2. Progression of his chronic kidney disease, which could lead to further electrolyte imbalances and acid-base disturbances.
3. Development of a urinary tract infection, which could lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction.
4. Worsening of his skin changes, which could lead to further tissue damage and potential complications such as cellulitis or gangrene.
5. Development of a deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism, which could lead to further complications such as pulmonary hypertension and right heart failure.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his condition to prevent these potential complications and optimize his outcomes.

   and supratherapeutic INR.   Perhaps anxiety provoked his flash
   pulmonary edema, but unclear if vice-versa is the case. Will attempt to
   control triggers of anxiety and constipation.
   - Goal: 1L out today
   - Continue spironolactone 12.5mg daily, titrate to 25mg daily in the
   next day
   - Stop lasix drip
   - Restart home dose of torsemide
   - Amytriptyline started [**9-21**], will monitor QT interval (slightly
   prolonged on recent EKG)
   - Isordil 10mg tid with MAP goal >50 in attempt to prevent pulmonary
   edema, will plan to increase to 25 TID on [**9-24**].
   .
   #  Pump:  Patient presented with fluid overload, likely exacerbation of
   well known systolic CHF (EF 20%). Pt with significant diuresis this
   stay, almost net negative 1L over past 24 hours, currently euvolemic.
   -Continue to diurese with lasix gtt and start spironolactone today
   .
   # Coronaries:  Patient has known CAD s/p CABG. Recent cath showed 2VD,
   patent LIMA to LAD, and diastolic dysfunction with no interventions
   performed.
   - Decrease ASA to 81mg daily
   - Continue ACE-I and BB, statin
   .
   # Rhythmn:  Currently in sinus with 1:1 conduction.  Patient has
   history of VF arrest with AICD removal given recurrent bloodstream
   infections.  Coumadin re-started yesterday, on Heparin drip.
   - monitor on telemetry
   - Continue Coumadin at home dose

   .

   yesterday evening (large, soft)
   - Patient denies prior colonoscopy; consider colonoscopy as outpatient
   .
   #  Blood pressure: Tolerating SBPs in the 80s.
   - Anti-hypertensive regimen as above.
   .
   # Anemia: stable, chronic.  Transfusion not indicated at this time.
   .
   # R leg ulcer: s/p surgical debridement by VSurg [**9-8**]. Wound VAC placed
   [**9-9**], now without wound vac in place.  No new vascular recs.
   -continue wound care per wound care recs.
   - D/C Percocet
   - Standing Tylenol
   - Re-start Oxycodone prn pain
   .
   # AVR: Goal INR 2.5 - 3.5. INR today is 2.7.
   - Continue coumadin at home dose, 5 mg daily
   .
   # DM 2:  Continue glargine 120 u qHS, ISS with accuchecks.
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: Continue atorvastatin.
   .
   # Hep C:  Per Hepatology, deferring treatment for now. [**Month (only) 60**] consider
   reassessment if patient continues to improve.
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Not currently on thyroid replacement therapy given
   that last TSH was appropriate.
   .

   decline in K.  Expect to stabilize with discontinuation of lasix gtt
   and spironolactone.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual with a complex medical history, currently admitted to the ICU for management of acute on chronic systolic and diastolic CHF, hypoxic respiratory failure, renal impairment, and peripheral vascular disease. The patient's condition has been stable overnight, with no significant changes in vital signs or laboratory values. The patient continues to receive various medications, including diuretics, anticoagulants, and antibiotics, and is being closely monitored for potential complications.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient's condition is characterized by repeated episodes of flash pulmonary edema, which may be exacerbated by anxiety, constipation, or other triggers. Close monitoring of oxygen saturation and respiratory status is essential to prevent further deterioration.
2. Cardiac Complications: The patient has a history of CAD, CABG, and diastolic dysfunction, which may increase the risk of cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or cardiac arrest. Close monitoring of cardiac rhythm and function is necessary to detect any changes.
3. Renal Impairment: The patient's renal function is impaired, which may increase the risk of acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease. Close monitoring of renal function and electrolyte levels is essential to prevent further deterioration.
4. Peripheral Vascular Disease: The patient has a history of peripheral vascular disease, which may increase the risk of complications such as limb ischemia or gangrene. Close monitoring of peripheral circulation and wound care is necessary to prevent further complications.
5. Anticoagulation: The patient is receiving anticoagulation therapy, which may increase the risk of bleeding complications. Close monitoring of bleeding risk and INR levels is essential to prevent further complications.
6. Infection: The patient has a positive urine culture for ESBL Klebsiella, which may increase the risk of sepsis or other infection-related complications. Close monitoring of infection risk and antibiotic therapy is necessary to prevent further complications.
7. Constipation: The patient's constipation may worsen if not managed effectively, which may increase the risk of complications such as bowel obstruction or perforation. Close monitoring of bowel function and constipation management is necessary to prevent further complications.
8. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may worsen if not managed effectively, which may increase the risk of complications such as cognitive impairment or cardiovascular disease. Close monitoring of thyroid function and replacement therapy is necessary to prevent further complications.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications and optimize their clinical outcome.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual with a complex medical history, including chronic systolic and diastolic heart failure, peripheral vascular disease, and hypoxic respiratory failure. They have been admitted to the ICU for multiple episodes of flash pulmonary edema, requiring intubation, and have a history of recurrent bloodstream infections leading to the removal of an AICD. The patient's current condition includes:

* Hypoxic respiratory failure with flash pulmonary edema
* Acute kidney injury with oliguria
* Chronic anemia
* R leg ulcer
* Known CAD with patent LIMA to LAD and diastolic dysfunction
* Supratherapeutic INR
* Positive urine culture for ESBL Klebsiella
* Constipation
* Hypokalemia

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.4°C (97.6°F)
* Heart rate: 64 bpm
* Blood pressure: 90/44 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 17 breaths/min
* SpO2: 96%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 8.0
* Hct: 25.9%
* Plt: 317 K/uL
* Cr: 1.3 mg/dL
* TropT: 0.11 ng/mL
* TCO2: 31 mmHg
* Glucose: 296 mg/dL

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pneumonia: Given the patient's history of recurrent bloodstream infections and the presence of a positive urine culture, there is a risk of developing pneumonia.
2. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's current oliguria and elevated creatinine levels indicate ongoing kidney injury, which may require further management.
3. Cardiac Complications: The patient's history of CAD, patent LIMA to LAD, and diastolic dysfunction puts them at risk for cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or cardiac arrest.
4. Bleeding Complications: The patient's supratherapeutic INR and history of recurrent bloodstream infections increase the risk of bleeding complications.
5. Infection: The patient's positive urine culture and history of recurrent bloodstream infections suggest a high risk of developing further infections.
6. Respiratory Failure: The patient's hypoxic respiratory failure and history of flash pulmonary edema put them at risk for further respiratory failure.
7. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's history of CAD and patent LIMA to LAD may increase the risk of cardiovascular complications such as ACS or PE.

Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status.
2. Adjust the patient's medication regimen as needed to manage their condition.
3. Consider further management of the patient's kidney function, including dialysis if necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust their medication regimen as needed to manage their cardiac condition.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust their oxygen therapy as needed.
6. Consider further management of the patient's infections, including antibiotics and antifungals if necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status and adjust their medication regimen as needed to manage their cardiovascular condition.

Summary:

The patient is a 109.4 kg male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of acute systolic heart failure on chronic heart failure. He has a history of constipation, pain control, anxiety, impaired aerobic capacity, and impaired gait. He is currently receiving furosemide (Lasix) infusion for heart failure, famotidine (Pepcid) for stress ulcer prophylaxis, and meropenem for possible urinary tract infection (UTI). His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.4°C, heart rate of 64 bpm, and blood pressure of 90/44 mmHg. He is receiving oxygen therapy at 2 L/min and has a SpO2 of 96%.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 8.0, hemoglobin of 7.5 g/dL, platelet count of 317 K/uL, and creatinine of 1.3 mg/dL. His troponin-T level is 0.11 ng/mL, and his lactate level is 32 mmol/L.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's UTI and elevated white blood cell count may increase the risk of sepsis.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's acute systolic heart failure and electrolyte imbalance may increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic heart failure and acute exacerbation may increase the risk of respiratory failure.
4. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine level and potential sepsis may increase the risk of renal failure.
5. Constipation: The patient's constipation may lead to bowel obstruction and potentially life-threatening complications.
6. Pneumonia: The patient's risk factors for pneumonia, such as chronic heart failure and immunosuppression, may increase the risk of developing pneumonia.
7. Wound infection: The patient's impaired skin integrity may increase the risk of wound infection.
8. DVT: The patient's risk factors for DVT, such as immobility and heart failure, may increase the risk of developing DVT.
9. VAP: The patient's risk factors for VAP, such as mechanical ventilation and impaired lung function, may increase the risk of developing VAP.

Summary:

The patient is a 109.4 kg male admitted to the ICU with a history of chronic systolic heart failure, acute on chronic. He has been experiencing constipation, pain, anxiety, impaired aerobic capacity, and urinary tract infection. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.4°C, heart rate of 64 bpm, blood pressure of 90/44 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 96%. He has a harsh systolic murmur and mild rales at the left posterior base. His laboratory results show elevated troponin levels, decreased hemoglobin, and increased white blood cell count.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and increased troponin levels may indicate the presence of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and mortality.
2. Heart failure: The patient's history of chronic systolic heart failure, acute on chronic, and his current symptoms of hypotension and tachycardia may indicate worsening heart failure, which can lead to cardiogenic shock and death.
3. Constipation: The patient's constipation may lead to bowel obstruction, which can cause abdominal distension, pain, and potentially life-threatening complications.
4. Urinary tract infection: The patient's urinary tract infection may spread to the kidneys, leading to sepsis and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. Skin integrity: The patient's history of impaired skin integrity and his current symptoms of vascular insufficiency and browning changes in his right leg may indicate the presence of pressure ulcers, which can lead to infection and potentially life-threatening complications.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of chronic heart failure and his current symptoms of constipation and pain may indicate the presence of gastrointestinal bleeding, which can lead to hypovolemic shock and potentially life-threatening complications.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient's history of chronic heart failure and his current symptoms of hypotension and tachycardia may indicate the presence of respiratory failure, which can lead to respiratory acidosis and potentially life-threatening complications.

Based on these potential medical complications, it is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and provide appropriate treatment to prevent and manage these complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Patient has had multiple episodes of
   flash pulmonary edema requiring intubation during his multiple MICU and
   CCU admissions; this episode was consistent with prior episodes.
   Although flash pulmonary edema is the most likely etiology of his
   hypoxic respiratory failure, other potential etiologies include ACS or
   PE, although these are less likely given his history, unchanged ECGs,
   and supratherapeutic INR.   Perhaps anxiety provoked his flash
   pulmonary edema, but unclear if vice-versa is the case. Will attempt to
   control triggers of anxiety (ie: constipation). Extubated yesterday
   successfully ([**9-21**]).
   - Goal: 1L out today
   - Start spironolactone 12.5mg daily
   - Continue lasix drip at 20mg/hour and titrate as needed to meet goal
   diuresis
   - Amytriptyline started [**9-21**], will monitor QT interval
   - Isordil 10mg tid with MAP goal >50 in attempt to prevent pulmonary
   edema
   .
   #  Pump:  Patient presented with fluid overload, likely exacerbation of
   well known systolic CHF (EF 20%). Pt with significant diuresis this
   stay, almost net negative 1L over past 24 hours.
   -Continue to diurese with lasix gtt and start spironolactone today
   .
   # UTI: Pt urine culture positive for ESBL Klebsiella.
   - Condom catheter to monitor I/Os, UOP
   - Continue meropenem for 14 d course (day 1=[**9-20**]).
   .
   # Coronaries:  Patient has known CAD s/p CABG. Recent cath showed 2VD,
   patent LIMA to LAD, and diastolic dysfunction with no interventions
   performed.
   - Continue ASA and statin
   - Continue ACE-I and BB
   .
   # Rhythmn:  Currently in sinus with 1:1 conduction.  Patient has
   history of VF arrest with AICD removal given recurrent bloodstream
   infections.
   -monitor on telemetry
   .
   #  Constipation:
   - Continue bowel regimen (feels constipated, although last BM was
   yesterday evening (large, soft))
   - Patient denies prior colonoscopy; consider colonoscopy as outpatient
   .
   #  Blood pressure: Tolerating SBPs in the 80s.
   - Anti-hypertensive regimen as above.
   .
   # R leg ulcer: s/p surgical debridement by VSurg [**9-8**]. Wound VAC placed
   [**9-9**].  Most recent wound care rec is to not have a VAC in place
   (previously was: continue wound VAC with replacement 3x/wk (MWF
   schedule)).
   - Follow-up vascular recommendations today
   .
   # AVR: Goal INR 2.5 - 3.5. INR today is 2.7.
   - Resume coumadin at home dose, 5 mg daily
   .
   # DM 2:  Continue glargine 120 u qHS, ISS with accuchecks.
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: Continue atorvastatin.
   .
   # Hep C:  Per Hepatology, deferring treatment for now. [**Month (only) 60**] consider
   reassessment if patient continues to improve.
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Not currently on thyroid replacement therapy given
   that last TSH was appropriate.
   .
   # Hypokalemia:
   - Not going to replete K as starting spironolocatone
   - Check 3pm electrolytes
   ICU Care

Based on the patient's progress note, the following information can be summarized:

The patient is a 65-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a history of systolic heart failure, coronary artery disease, and previous cardiac arrest. He has been diagnosed with hypoxic respiratory failure, likely due to flash pulmonary edema, and is being treated with diuretics and oxygen therapy. His blood pressure is currently running in the low 80s and high 70s, and he is tolerating this level of blood pressure.

The patient has a history of recurrent bloodstream infections, which has led to the removal of his automatic implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD). He is currently in sinus rhythm with 1:1 conduction and is being monitored on telemetry.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of troponin, CK, and CKMB, indicating cardiac damage. His electrolyte levels are slightly abnormal, with a potassium level of 3.7 mEq/L and a magnesium level of 1.2 mg/dL.

The patient's medical history includes chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), coronary artery disease, and a history of flash pulmonary edema. He has also been diagnosed with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and hypothyroidism.

The patient's current medications include aspirin, statin, ACE inhibitor, beta blocker, and diuretics. He is also taking antibiotics for a urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by an extended-spectrum beta-lactamase (ESBL) Klebsiella.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the patient's condition include:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's history of flash pulmonary edema and hypoxic respiratory failure makes him susceptible to developing pneumonia.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and his current condition make him at risk for developing cardiac arrhythmias, such as ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.
3. Sepsis: The patient's UTI and his history of recurrent bloodstream infections make him at risk for developing sepsis.
4. Renal failure: The patient's history of systolic heart failure and his current condition make him at risk for developing renal failure.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of peptic ulcer disease and his current condition make him at risk for developing gastrointestinal bleeding.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent complications and ensure optimal outcomes.

The patient has a significant amount of fluid overload, with a net negative 1L fluid balance over the past 24 hours. He has been diuresed with Lasix and is currently euvolemic.

The patient has a history of flash pulmonary edema, and the current episode is likely related to this condition. Other potential etiologies include acute coronary syndrome (ACS) or pulmonary embolism (PE), although these are less likely given the patient's history and unchanged ECGs.

The patient's medication regimen includes:

* Lasix drip stopped, restarted with Torsemide
* Amytriptyline started for anxiety
* Isordil 10mg tid for pulmonary edema prevention
* Coumadin 5mg daily for atrial fibrillation
* Heparin drip for deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Pulmonary edema
* Fluid overload
* Hypotension
* Acute kidney injury
* Gastrointestinal bleeding
* Infection (UTI)
* Constipation
* Hyperkalemia
* Hypothyroidism
* Hepatitis C

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue spironolactone and titrate to 25mg daily
* Restart Torsemide
* Monitor QT interval with Amytriptyline

* Continue Coumadin and Heparin drip
* Monitor INR and adjust as needed

* Monitor for signs of infection and take appropriate action
* Monitor for signs of constipation and take appropriate action
* Monitor for signs of hyperkalemia and take appropriate action
* Monitor for signs of hypothyroidism and take appropriate action
* Monitor for signs of hepatitis C and take appropriate action

Summary:

The patient is a 65-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of systolic heart failure, coronary artery disease, and chronic venous stasis changes in his right leg. He has been experiencing flash pulmonary edema, requiring intubation multiple times in the past. His current condition is stable, with a blood pressure running in the low 80s and high 70s, and he is complaining of right foot pain. He has a known allergy to penicillin and is currently taking various medications, including lasix, spironolactone, and amytriptyline.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 8.0, a hemoglobin level of 7.5 g/dL, and a platelet count of 274. His troponin level is 0.11 ng/mL, and his creatinine level is 1.3 mg/dL. His blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 32 mg/dL, and his creatinine level is 1.2 mg/dL. His glucose level is 296 mg/dL, and his troponin-T level is 0.12 ng/mL.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient has a history of flash pulmonary edema, which can lead to hypoxic respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has a history of ventricular fibrillation and is currently taking medications that can affect his cardiac rhythm.
3. Sepsis: The patient has a urinary tract infection (UTI) and is at risk for developing sepsis.
4. Kidney damage: The patient has a history of chronic kidney disease and is at risk for further kidney damage due to his medications and underlying condition.
5. Constipation: The patient is experiencing constipation and is at risk for developing bowel obstruction or perforation.
6. Wound infection: The patient has a right leg ulcer and is at risk for developing a wound infection.
7. Hyperkalemia: The patient is at risk for developing hyperkalemia due to his medications and underlying condition.
8. Hypothyroidism: The patient has a history of hypothyroidism and is at risk for developing hypothyroidism due to his medications and underlying condition.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is stable, and his medications are being adjusted to manage his symptoms. He is being monitored closely for any signs of deterioration, and his laboratory results are being closely monitored. The patient's wound is being cared for, and he is being treated for his UTI. The patient's cardiac status is being closely monitored, and he is being treated for his cardiac arrhythmias. The patient's blood pressure is being monitored closely, and he is being treated for his hypertension.

* SpO2: 96%

The patient has a history of flash pulmonary edema, which is the most likely etiology of his current hypoxic respiratory failure. However, other potential etiologies include acute coronary syndrome (ACS) or pulmonary embolism (PE), although these are less likely given his history and unchanged ECGs. The patient's supratherapeutic INR suggests that he may be at risk for bleeding.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 8.0 x 10^9/L
* Hct: 25.9%
* Plt: 317 x 10^9/L
* Cr: 1.3 mg/dL
* TropT: 0.11 ng/mL
* TCO2: 31 mmHg
* Glucose: 296 mg/dL

The patient's medications include:

* Lasix drip (stopped)
* Spironolactone 12.5mg daily (titrated to 25mg daily)
* Torsemide ( restarted)
* Amytriptyline (started)
* Isordil 10mg tid
* Coumadin 5mg daily
* ACE-I and BB
* Statin
* Meropenem (continued for 14 days)
* Heparin drip

The patient's plan includes:

* Goal: 1L out today
* Continue spironolactone 12.5mg daily, titrate to 25mg daily in the next day
* Stop lasix drip
* Restart home dose of torsemide
* Amytriptyline started, monitor QT interval
* Isordil 10mg tid with MAP goal >50 in attempt to prevent pulmonary edema
* Continue Coumadin at home dose
* Continue Heparin drip with goal PTT 60-80

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Bleeding due to supratherapeutic INR
* Pulmonary edema due to continued fluid overload or hypertension
* Cardiac arrhythmias due to electrolyte imbalances or medication interactions
* Infection due to prolonged hospitalization and antibiotic use
* Constipation due to lack of bowel movement and medication use
* Anemia due to chronic disease and potential bleeding
* Wound infection or complications due to surgical debridement and wound care

It is essential to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust his medications and treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Patient has had multiple episodes of
   flash pulmonary edema requiring intubation during his multiple MICU and
   CCU admissions; this episode was consistent with prior episodes.
   Although flash pulmonary edema is the most likely etiology of his
   hypoxic respiratory failure, other potential etiologies include ACS or
   PE, although these are less likely given his history, unchanged ECGs,
   and supratherapeutic INR.   Perhaps anxiety provoked his flash
   pulmonary edema, but unclear if vice-versa is the case. Will attempt to
   control triggers of anxiety (ie: constipation). Extubated yesterday
   successfully ([**9-21**]).
   - Goal: 1L out today
   - Start spironolactone 12.5mg daily
   - Continue lasix drip at 20mg/hour and titrate as needed to meet goal
   diuresis
   - Amytriptyline started [**9-21**], will monitor QT interval
   - Isordil 10mg tid with MAP goal >50 in attempt to prevent pulmonary
   edema
   .
   #  Pump:  Patient presented with fluid overload, likely exacerbation of
   well known systolic CHF (EF 20%). Pt with significant diuresis this
   stay, almost net negative 1L over past 24 hours.
   -Continue to diurese with lasix gtt and start spironolactone today
   .
   # Coronaries:  Patient has known CAD s/p CABG. Recent cath showed 2VD,
   patent LIMA to LAD, and diastolic dysfunction with no interventions
   performed.
   - Continue ASA and statin
   - Continue ACE-I and BB
   .
   # Rhythmn:  Currently in sinus with 1:1 conduction.  Patient has
   history of VF arrest with AICD removal given recurrent bloodstream
   infections.
   -monitor on telemetry
   .
   # UTI: Pt urine culture positive for ESBL Klebsiella.
   - Condom catheter to monitor I/Os, UOP
   - Continue meropenem for 14 d course (day 1=[**9-20**]).
   .
   #  Constipation:
   - Continue bowel regimen (feels constipated, although last BM was
   yesterday evening (large, soft))
   - Patient denies prior colonoscopy; consider colonoscopy as outpatient
   .
   #  Blood pressure: Tolerating SBPs in the 80s.
   - Anti-hypertensive regimen as above.
   .
   # R leg ulcer: s/p surgical debridement by VSurg [**9-8**]. Wound VAC placed
   [**9-9**], now without wound vac in place.
   - continue scheduled dressing changes.
   - Follow-up vascular recommendations today
   .
   # AVR: Goal INR 2.5 - 3.5. INR today is 2.7.
   - Resume coumadin at home dose, 5 mg daily
   .
   # DM 2:  Continue glargine 120 u qHS, ISS with accuchecks.
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: Continue atorvastatin.
   .
   # Hep C:  Per Hepatology, deferring treatment for now. [**Month (only) 60**] consider
   reassessment if patient continues to improve.
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Not currently on thyroid replacement therapy given
   that last TSH was appropriate.
   .
   # Hypokalemia:
   - Not going to replete K as starting spironolocatone
   - Check 3pm electrolytes
   ICU Care

* Spironolactone 12.5 mg daily
* Amytriptyline
* Isordil 10mg tid
* Aspirin and statin for coronary artery disease
* ACE-I and BB for heart failure
* Coumadin for atrial fibrillation
* Meropenem for UTI

The patient's plan includes:

* Goal: 1L out today
* Continue lasix drip at 20mg/hour and titrate as needed to meet goal diuresis
* Monitor QT interval
* Isordil 10mg tid with MAP goal >50 in attempt to prevent pulmonary edema
* Continue ASA and statin
* Continue ACE-I and BB
* Monitor on telemetry
* Continue meropenem for 14-day course
* Continue bowel regimen
* Resume coumadin at home dose
* Follow-up vascular recommendations
* Check 3pm electrolytes

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

* Flash pulmonary edema
* Respiratory failure
* Sepsis
* Cardiac arrest
* Deep vein thrombosis
* Pulmonary embolism
* UTI
* Constipation
* Hypokalemia
* Hypothyroidism

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and medications to prevent and manage these potential complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications are noted:

Summary:

* The patient is a 65-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of systolic heart failure, coronary artery disease, and chronic venous stasis changes in the right leg.
* He has had multiple episodes of flash pulmonary edema requiring intubation, and is currently being treated for hypoxic respiratory failure.
* The patient is also being managed for fluid overload, and has had significant diuresis this stay.
* He has a positive urine culture for ESBL Klebsiella, and is being treated with meropenem.
* The patient has a history of VF arrest with AICD removal, and is currently in sinus rhythm with 1:1 conduction.
* He has constipation and is being managed with a bowel regimen.
* The patient has a right leg ulcer and is being followed up with vascular recommendations.
* He is being treated for hypertension, and has a goal INR of 2.5-3.5.

Potential Medical Complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's history of flash pulmonary edema and hypoxic respiratory failure puts him at risk for further respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or respiratory distress syndrome.
* Sepsis: The patient's positive urine culture for ESBL Klebsiella and ongoing antibiotic treatment for UTI increases his risk of developing sepsis.
* Bleeding: The patient's history of VF arrest and AICD removal, as well as his current use of anticoagulant therapy, increases his risk of bleeding complications.
* Wound infection: The patient's right leg ulcer and ongoing wound care may increase his risk of developing wound infection.
* Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's use of diuretics and potential changes in his electrolyte levels may increase his risk of developing electrolyte imbalances, such as hypokalemia.
* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of VF arrest and current use of antiarrhythmic medications increases his risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's constipation and potential use of anti-diarrheal medications may increase his risk of developing gastrointestinal complications, such as bowel obstruction or perforation.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for various medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent these complications and ensure the patient's optimal care.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following information can be summarized:

* The patient has been admitted to the ICU for hypoxic respiratory failure, which is likely due to flash pulmonary edema, although other potential etiologies include acute coronary syndrome (ACS) or pulmonary embolism (PE).
* The patient has a history of systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 20%, and has undergone coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).
* The patient has been treated with diuretics, including spironolactone and torsemide, to manage fluid overload and systolic heart failure.
* The patient has also been treated with anticoagulants, including warfarin and heparin, to manage atrial fibrillation and prevent stroke.
* The patient has a urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by an extended-spectrum beta-lactamase (ESBL) Klebsiella, and is being treated with meropenem.
* The patient has a right leg ulcer that was surgically debrided and is now being treated with wound care and pain management.
* The patient has a history of hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, and hypothyroidism, and is being treated with medications to manage these conditions.
* The patient's electrolytes, including potassium, sodium, and magnesium, are being monitored and repleted as needed.
* The patient's nutrition is being managed with a heart-healthy and diabetic diet, and their glycemic control is being monitored with insulin glargine and sliding scale (SS) insulin.
* The patient's lines, including a peripheral intravenous (PIV) line and a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) line, are being monitored and maintained.
* The patient is being prophylaxed for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) with warfarin and heparin, and for stress ulcers with H2 blockers.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Continued hypoxic respiratory failure, which could lead to further respiratory distress and potential need for intubation.
* Systolic and diastolic heart failure, which could lead to further fluid overload and potential need for diuretic therapy.
* UTI, which could lead to sepsis and potential need for antibiotics.

   # Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Patient has had multiple episodes of

   hypoxic respiratory failure, other potential etiologies include ACS or
   PE, although these are less likely given his history, unchanged ECGs,
   and supratherapeutic INR.   Perhaps anxiety provoked his flash
   pulmonary edema, but unclear if vice-versa is the case. Will attempt to
   control triggers of anxiety and constipation.
   - Goal: 1 L out today
   - Increase spironolactone  to 25mg daily
   - Continue torsemide

   - Increase Isordil to 20mg TID
   - Goal SBP < 130 to prevent flash pulmonary edema
   .

   well known systolic CHF (EF 20%). Pt with significant diuresis this
   stay, almost net negative 1L over past 24 hours, currently euvolemic on
   exam.
   -Continue to diurese, with spironolcatone and torsemide, goal 1L out
   today
   .

   patent LIMA to LAD, and diastolic dysfunction with no interventions
   performed.
   - ASA 81mg daily
   - Continue ACE-I and BB, statin
   .

   history of VF arrest with AICD removal given recurrent bloodstream
   infections.  INR 2.4 so continue coumadin, on Heparin drip until
   therapeutic.

   - Continue Coumadin at home dose
   - Continue Heparin drip until INR therapeutic
   .

   - Condom catheter to monitor I/Os, UOP
   - Continue Meropenem for 14 d course (day 1=[**9-20**]).
   .

   - Continue bowel regimen
   - Patient denies prior colonoscopy; consider colonoscopy as outpatient
   .
   #  Blood pressure: Tolerating SBPs in the 80s. Goal SBP < 130.
   - Anti-hypertensive regimen as above.
   .
   # Anemia: stable, chronic.  Transfusion not indicated at this time.
   .
   # R leg ulcer: s/p surgical debridement by VSurg [**9-8**]. Wound VAC placed
   [**9-9**], now without wound vac in place.  No new vascular recs.
   - continue wound care per wound care recs.
   - Standing Tylenol
   - Oxycodone prn pain
   .
   # AVR: Goal INR 2.5 - 3.5. INR today is 2.4.
   - Continue coumadin at home dose, 5 mg daily
   - Continue heparin gtt until therapeutic with coumadin
   .
   # DM 2:  Continue glargine 120 u qHS, ISS with accuchecks.
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: Continue atorvastatin.
   .
   # Hep C:  Per Hepatology, deferring treatment for now. [**Month (only) 60**] consider

   .
